newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Chechen leader offers reward for missing reporters.
newsitem.headline: Chechen leader offers reward for missing reporters.

text.p: Chechnya's President Aslan Maskhadov has offered a reward of $100,000 for information on the whereabouts of seven Russian journalists abducted by bandits in the turbulent region, Interfax news agency said on Saturday.
The Chechen authorities have also pledged anonymity for anybody coming forward with information, it said.

Interior Minister Kazbek Makhashev went on local television to appeal for the journalists' immediate release and said their kidnappers might face the death penalty. The missing journalists include a correspondent of Itar-Tass news agency and three Radio Russia reporters, abducted several months ago, and an NTV television film crew who disappeared earlier this month.

The kidnappings have undermined Chechnya's efforts to restore order and stability since a peace deal last August put an end to 21 months of bloody fighting between pro-independence rebels and Russian troops.
Other journalists have been kidnapped in recent months, including an Italian photographer, but have later been released.
In a further worrying development on Saturday, one of the candidates for the post of mayor in Chechnya's capital Grozny went missing and his car was found burned out, Interfax said.
It said Yakub Usmanov was one of the leading candidates and had been due to meet the mayor of Moscow Yuri Luzhkov on Saturday in the Russian capital.
Local and parliamentary elections are due to be held in Chechnya on May 31.
Interfax quoted Usmanov's National Independence Party as saying the apparent abduction was an "extremely serious challenge" to the Chechen authorities.
Earlier this month Maskhadov and Russia's President Boris Yeltsin signed a peace accord, promising an end to 400 years of intermittent conflict between Moscow and the oil-rich north Caucasus region.

Under last August's truce a final decision on the vexed issue of Chechnya's status has been deferred until 2001. The Chechens want full independence but Moscow says Chechnya must remain part of Russia.
